content: How can I help you today?

Well, I've been having a hard time sleeping, and it feels like everything is just piling up on me. Work has been really stressful, and I’m constantly worried about losing my job. I can't seem to stop my mind from racing at night, and I usually end up scrolling on my phone, which doesn’t seem to help. My partner suggested I try talking to someone, so here I am.

It sounds like there’s been a lot weighing on you lately—stress from work, worry about job security, and sleepless nights. It’s understandable that all of this is overwhelming and impacting how you feel. Your partner's suggestion to talk to someone shows they care about you and want to support you. How do you feel about being here and sharing this today?

I’m not gonna lie, I feel kind of skeptical about this whole thing. I’m not sure if talking is going to do much to actually help, but I guess I’m here because I want to try something—anything—to feel better. I just don’t know where to even start.

It’s completely okay to feel skeptical—it takes courage to try something new, especially when you’re not sure it will help. The fact that you’re willing to give this a chance shows that you’re open to exploring ways to feel better. Starting can feel overwhelming, but it’s a step forward. What’s the most pressing thing on your mind right now? Maybe we can start there.

Honestly, the work stuff is eating away at me the most. I'm constantly thinking about whether I’ll get laid off and how I’d even manage if that happened. It's like this never-ending loop in my head that leaves me exhausted but still unable to sleep. I want to fix everything, but I feel stuck.

It sounds like the uncertainty around work is taking up a lot of mental space and creating exhaustion for you—but at the same time, it’s hard to turn it off. Feeling stuck in that loop can make it hard to see a way forward. You’ve mentioned wanting to fix things—what does that mean for you right now, when it comes to the stress you’re facing?

I guess it means I want to stop feeling so anxious all the time. I want to feel like I’m in control again, like I’m able to sleep and focus instead of just worrying endlessly. But with everything going on, it feels impossible to get to that place.

Wanting to feel in control again and ease the constant anxiety makes a lot of sense—you clearly value having balance in your life. Right now, it feels unreachable, but even acknowledging what you want is an important step. What do you think has helped you in the past when stress felt overwhelming, or have you found anything lately that even slightly helps?

Honestly, I’m not sure what’s helped before. Lately, I just try to distract myself with my phone or TV, but it doesn’t really stop the worrying—it just makes my head busier. I haven’t really found anything that works, which is why I feel stuck.

Trying to distract yourself sounds like a way you’ve been attempting to cope, even if it hasn’t provided the relief you’re looking for. Feeling stuck can make it hard to figure out what might help. What’s something small or simple you think might calm your mind, even just a little, if you were able to give it a try?

I don’t really know what would help, honestly. Maybe trying to put my phone away before bed? But even that feels easier said than done—when I’m anxious, it’s just so tempting to reach for it. I’m not sure I can trust myself to stick to something like that.

It sounds like you’re aware that your phone might be contributing to the restless nights, but it’s tough to resist when anxiety kicks in. That shows you’re already reflecting on what could help, which is a meaningful first step. Building trust in yourself can take time, and small steps can feel more doable. What do you think is one realistic, manageable action you could try that doesn’t feel overwhelming right now?

I’m not sure, but maybe setting a limit like charging my phone in another room? That way it’s not right there for me to grab, but I don’t know if I’ll actually follow through with it. It’s hard to imagine breaking that habit when I’m so used to it.

Charging your phone in another room sounds like a thoughtful idea—it creates some physical distance, which might help reduce the temptation. You’re also being realistic about how challenging it might be to follow through, which is understandable when habits are deeply ingrained. What do you think might make it easier to start this change, even if it’s just experimenting with it for a night or two?

Maybe if I had something else to keep me distracted, like reading a book or listening to calming music instead, it could help me not reach for my phone. It’s just hard to imagine doing it when I’m so used to grabbing my phone automatically. I’d probably have to start small, and even then, I’m not sure it would work.

It’s really insightful that you’re considering alternatives, like reading or listening to calming music, to fill that gap and break the automatic habit of reaching for your phone. Starting small is a wise approach—it makes the change feel less intimidating, and you can figure out what works for you over time. How would you feel about trying one of those strategies for just a night or two and seeing how it goes?

I might be open to trying it for a night or two, just to see if it makes any difference. I’m still not sure how much it would actually help, but I guess there’s no harm in giving it a shot. It’s worth a try, right?

Absolutely—it’s worth a try, and even small steps like experimenting for a night or two can give you insight into what helps and what doesn’t. The key is giving yourself permission to take it slow and adjust as needed. Is there anything else you’d like to talk about or explore before thinking about how you might approach this?
Actually, I think I’m good for now. Thank you for helping me talk this through—I’ll give those ideas a try and see how it goes. Maybe I’ll check back in if I feel like I need more help.
